results.title: First Resistance to Taliban Rule Tests Afghanistan’s Uncertain Future
results.abstract: While the militants appear firmly in control, some prominent figures vowed to continue resistance as protests erupted in two cities and millions of Afghans parsed clues about the Taliban’s intentions.

results.title: The Dangerous Road to the Kabul Airport
results.abstract: Thousands of people have headed to the airport trying to flee, but Taliban fighters have blocked entrances, fired rifles and beaten some people in the crowds.
results.byline: By Lauren Leatherby, Jim Huylebroek, Scott Reinhard and Sarah Kerr

results.title: Collapse and Conquest: The Taliban Strategy That Seized Afghanistan

results.title: To China, Afghan Fall Proves U.S. Hubris. It Also Brings New Dangers.

results.abstract: The impact of a magnitude-7.2 earthquake on Saturday was magnified Monday by heavy rains and wind from Grace, then a tropical depression, which would soon strengthen into a tropical storm.
results.byline: By Tim Wallace, Ashley Wu and Jugal K. Patel

results.title: Bill Davis, Pragmatic Ontario Premier, Dies at 92
results.abstract: A champion of education in his province, he helped his nation achieve sovereignty from Britain by brokering a 1982 compromise.

multimedia.caption: Bill Davis, who was the premier of Ontario for 14 years, in an undated photo. He attributed his electoral success to a political pragmatism that left his rivals on the fringes.
multimedia.copyright: Reg Innell/Toronto Star, via Getty Images

results.title: The Afghan president who fled the country is now in the U.A.E.
results.abstract: The whereabouts Ashraf Ghani, whose departure from Afghanistan last weekend sped the government’s collapse, had been a matter of speculation for days.
results.byline: By Marc Santora, Matthew Rosenberg and Adam Nossiter

multimedia.caption: “If I had stayed, countless of my countrymen would be martyred and Kabul would face destruction,” President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan wrote on social media on Sunday.
multimedia.copyright: Sajjad Hussain/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

multimedia.caption: “If I had stayed, countless of my countrymen would be martyred and Kabul would face destruction,” President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan wrote on social media on Sunday.
multimedia.copyright: Sajjad Hussain/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

results.title: Chaos spreads outside Kabul’s airport as the Taliban try to control crowds.
results.abstract: The U.S. military has established control inside Kabul’s international airport. But the roads leading to the facility, where there are growing crowds and mayhem, are controlled by the Taliban.
results.byline: By Jim Huylebroek and Marc Santora

multimedia.caption: Gunshots rang out as thousands of Afghans crowded outside Kabul’s international airport attempting to flee the country. The Taliban controlled the chaotic streets surrounding the airport, while the U.S. military established control inside.
multimedia.copyright: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Gunshots rang out as thousands of Afghans crowded outside Kabul’s international airport attempting to flee the country. The Taliban controlled the chaotic streets surrounding the airport, while the U.S. military established control inside.

results.title: A First Amendment Precedent
results.abstract: The Supreme Court may reconsider a major case concerning freedom of the press. The Times’s Adam Liptak explains why.
